CONTENT: There were too many articles being written about how severely understaffed the L.A. Fire Department is in regards to the area they serve. Staff appropriately. Create an actual physical emergency system (like the ones they built in areas of the country that experience tornadoes). We need a better way. They are adapted to the region, save water, and provide fire resilience. It's a win for everyone!

CONTENT:
Over the last few years, as a private property owner, I have received Brush Clearance notices for my property. At one point, I was substantially fined - although I had documentation my lot was clear. No matter what had been happening in my life (a parent passing, Covid, a sick child) I was required to clear brush on my property. Why isn’t the City, County, State held to these same requirements? 

I also think basic services that prioritize the safety of our communities - the police, fire department, schools, infrastructure - need to be funded first. We pay too high of taxes in LA and CA for these services not be available to residents when they are needed (ie; firefighters to put out fires, fire hydrants that work, etc)
SUMMARY: City, County, State should be held to same brush clearance requirements as private property owners
LABEL: Unequal Enforcement Demanded

CONTENT: This has to become the rule in neighborhoods, block clubs, community organizations and cities in the County.  Citizens need to be prepared, informed, and ready to handle whatever comes their way in an emergency, assuming that no one is coming to save them.  We need to have EMT/CPR skills on our blocks, have a communication system that is analog in the case of no communication, and a way to account for and support each other in scenarios where city and county services are over-taxed and not able to provide the level of support needed.  We need to get EMERGENCY READY, whether for fires, floods, earthquakes, or more unthinkable events such as sabotaging our communications and other infrastructure, which are currently very vulnerable.

CONTENT: This fire was unprecedented in that the winds created a very fast moving fire.  I think the city did a good job alerting people to high fire risk prior to the windstorm, as long as residents were signed up for the city's NotifyLA system and looked at NOAA reports ahead of time.  I don't know how best to get alerts to all citizens, especially the elderly who may be technology averse.  Maybe start with a cell phone push to alert citizens of fire risk, and I think it is also the responsibility of the residents to prepare adequately too for rapid evacuation.
SUMMARY: City should alert citizens via cell phone push, but residents also have a responsibility to prepare for rapid evacuation.
LABEL: Shared Mutual Responsibility
SUBCAT_DESC: The comments strongly advocate for prioritizing fire prevention, maintenance, and preparedness measures over reactive responses, emphasizing the need for proactive government planning, homeowner responsibility, and systematic fire hazard mitigation before disasters occur.

CONTENT: Easy access to fire-safe building plans would help people tremendously, I think. I know some homeowners will struggle because they want to rebuild THE house, but many of those houses had outdated materials that are no longer up to code. But helping people see how they can rebuild with the proper materials will get some people over that hump quickly. Additionally, ADUs are a great way to help people earn extra income to cover their mortgages/insurance -- or to bring loved ones in when they need housing. This should be something that can be fast-tracked immediately. Long-term we all know that affordable housing is a challenge -- I'm not sure how we ever overcome the NIMBY mentality and make room for those who can't afford $3000 studio apts.
SUMMARY: Helping people rebuild with proper materials will get them over the hump quickly
LABEL: Rebuild With Resilience
SUBCAT_DESC: Comments advocate for rebuilding with climate resilience in mind, focusing on modern infrastructure improvements like underground power lines, fire-resistant materials, and sustainable building practices while allowing temporary housing solutions during reconstruction.

CONTENT: I was stunned to hear how many homes likely burned because of the mesh over the venting areas in roofs/attics. It seems clear this was a known issue -- instead of insurance companies canceling people, why not spend money on homeowner safety education? If people knew replacing that mesh might save their home, you're telling me more people wouldn't do it? Yet I never heard of that until these terrible fires. And if we don't do the work ahead of time -- firebreaks, education, and routinely evaluating the readiness of our agencies, then another disaster will happen, and I'm not sure how much more this state can take.
SUMMARY: Spending money on homeowner safety education could prevent homes from burning by informing them of simple fixes like replacing mesh over venting areas
LABEL: Collective Action Needed
SUBCAT_DESC: Communities must take the initiative in wildfire preparedness through neighborhood-level organization, education, and accountability rather than relying solely on government agencies or insurance companies. This includes property hardening, training, and establishing local emergency response networks.

CONTENT:
More education about fire prevention, such as removing furniture and storage from the house perimeter, not using wood for fences, maintaining fire extinguishers, fireproof vents, etc should be required by the county and inspected by insurance companies. 

Insurance companies already check for overhanging trees, which is a similar risk issue.  Aftermarket sprinklers should be required inside and outside the house.  

A siren alarm system such as that for tornadoes in other states is not costly. Cell phone alerts are not appropriate for middle of the night event.

My neighbors saved their houses by dousing small fires all night long.  When we are ordered to evacuate, the fire dept took the responsibility to save our homes.....and failed.
SUMMARY: County should require fire prevention measures like fireproof vents and aftermarket sprinklers, inspected by insurance companies.
LABEL: Collective Mandatory Standards
SUBCAT_DESC: Communities must take the initiative in wildfire preparedness through neighborhood-level organization, education, and accountability rather than relying solely on government agencies or insurance companies. This includes property hardening, training, and establishing local emergency response networks.

CONTENT: Sprinklers inside and out.  Rules for removing all flammable materials from house perimeter. Vents at chest level so they can be sealed conveniently as necessary. Instructions and training on how to do this for homeowners and renters.
SUMMARY: Sprinklers and sealed vents at chest level with training for homeowners and renters to mitigate fire risk.
LABEL: Collective Action Required

CONTENT: One area of enormous opportunity, with relevance to building codes, zoning, insurance and more, is seeking to systematically leverage the incredibly exciting advancements happening in the material sciences.  The news and announcement webpages of most (if not all) of our major goverment research labs, and many, many of our major research universities, are regularly peppered with summaries of material developments or breakthroughs in these fields having potential application to the built environment; whether for durability, for ability to sequester carbon, for ability to withstand high temperatures (i.e., fire resistent).  These pages often end with contact information to learn more and/or seek technology licensing.
SUMMARY: Leverage advancements in material sciences to build back with enhanced resilience measures
LABEL: Build Back Better
SUBCAT_DESC: Residents strongly advocate for reducing bureaucratic barriers, waiving permit fees, and simplifying building codes while maintaining essential safety standards to expedite post-fire reconstruction and prevent excessive costs for affected homeowners.

CONTENT: As a semi educated citizen and homeowner:  I think there are two kinds of fires.  The kind that starts in the typical neighborhood, and the giant super hot wildfire.  Both are worth preparing for, for sure, but I think we need to prioritize prevention and mitigation of wildfire above smaller measures that make no difference to a wildfire.  When I seek information, the advice is mixed together.  There's so much fire prevention advice that doesn't help in the case of wildfire, so increased awareness of what's relevant and what's not is called for.
SUMMARY: Homeowners need to prioritize wildfire prevention and mitigation, and receive clearer guidance on effective measures

CONTENT: On the topic of home rebuilding, I think it is critically important that the new homes are resilient to future disaster and energy efficient. The Passive Housing Standard (being considered by state legislators AB368) would be an excellent fit with super insulation, air-tight construction and better performing windows. This eliminates the pathways the fire used to penetrate houses. Additionally it offers improved air quality, reduced noise pollution, up to 50% energy savings and resilience in power outages. The rebuilds should adhere to reach codes of no gas hookups so the community can again reduce the danger of fires and also greatly reduce emissions/air quality in the community.
SUMMARY: Rebuilds should adhere to Passive Housing Standard and reach codes for no gas hookups to reduce fire danger and emissions.

CONTENT: Housing has been incredibly tough, expensive, and hard to find. Then the fires happened. People need to rebuild and live in their homes and sell to families, not corporations. CONTENT: Our utilities keep causing these devastating fires and they are getting worse with climate change. CONTENT: In our rural area, we've discovered the hard way that key equipment for landlines, cable/internet and cell service often shares a power pole. Which means literally every means of communication most people have access to goes down at the same time if the fire takes out that ONE pole. There ought to be a mandate for undergrounding ALL of those services and separating them where undergrounding is not possible. A grant program to equip rural residents with satellite phones for emergency use would also help, as would establishing local emergency radio frequencies we could tune into for updates. Also, cell phones should be able to connect to ANY available tower for ALL CALLS (not just 911) and alerts (nixle, watch duty, etc) during emergencies.
SUMMARY: There should be a mandate for undergrounding services and separating them when not possible, with potential grant programs for emergency equipment
LABEL: Public Takes Precedence
SUBCAT_DESC: Comments express strong opposition to private control of utilities, advocating for public ownership, underground power lines, and greater accountability from both private companies and government agencies in infrastructure management and disaster response.

CONTENT:
I am writing to bring attention to a critical gap in the recent executive order issued by Governor Gavin Newsom to expedite rebuilding efforts for residents affected by the current Los Angeles County wildfires. While this order offers a lifeline to those impacted by the Palisades and Eaton Fires, it excludes countless residents who have been struggling to rebuild their lives and homes after previous disasters, such as the Woolsey Fire (2018), Franklin Fire (2024),Mountain Fire(2024) Bobcat Fire (2020), Creek Fire (2017), Sand Fire (2016), La Tuna Fire (2017), and Saddleridge Fire (2019). I am sure there are others that I am missing.


These past fires left thousands of Californians grappling with complex permitting processes.
SUMMARY: Governor Newsom's executive order expedites rebuilding for recent wildfire victims, but excludes those from previous disasters
LABEL: Prioritize Recent Victims

Building methods—


There’s a huge opportunity for LA to rebuild using sustainable fire safe building methods. For the sake of the entire state, proven building methods, using straw bale, hempcrete, etc could be employed to demonstrate that we don’t need to continue in our previously standard methods that burn down so easily and are costing a fortune to insure. 

Let’s think outside the box and not be controlled by monied interests. Let’s promote building practices and accompanying policies that make the insurance companies give major reductions to fire insurance premiums that will last in an increasingly fire prone environment.

CONTENT: How much longer must the public die at the hands of private corporations? Enough is enough. Create public utility systems now. It will create more jobs and will (hopefully) be updated and cared for better than private corporations ever have. Also, make internet access a human right and also a public utility. To only have one option in an area means these private corporations can charge whatever they want. It's 2025 - the internet should be accessible to all. For managing our water systems - look to Tucson, AZ. They sequester more than enough rain water to last them all year. As droughts get worse, we must sequester as much water as possible, instead of having it wash away into the ocean. There are solutions, we just need to implement them.
SUMMARY: Create public utility systems now to prevent public deaths at the hands of private corporations

Because I was 1 block outside "the fire zone" I didn't qualify for help even though had an apartment filled with ash. Fights with landlord ensued and there was no protection from eviction.

I have some ALE but it took a long while to kick in and I had no idea how to navigate it. I still need help understanding how insurance can help

CONTENT:
The fires were & are a continuing catastrophe
The faster we organize & implement recovery measures the long-term economic damage will be

To achieve this will require an innovative and comprehensive plan which addresses present, short & long term challenges all at once

 We MUST take into consideration the increasing demand for limited water & power resources as the population continues to grow.
Think for a moment of the consequences if we ignore this...

We have all of the resources we need to make an outstanding accomplishment, to rise from the ashes like the Phoenix

Extreme & erratic weather events are increasing around the globe.

Let it be  L.A.

CONTENT: Power lines need to be underground.  Europe has them, why doesn't California? Leadership should be held accountable for not maintaining fire hydrants and reservoirs. CONTENT: In times of emergency, we often fall back on the same inefficient routines simply because they’re familiar. But crises should push us to rethink—not repeat—our processes. This is the moment to evaluate, and rebuild smarter on all levels in LA. By focusing on the shortest path to effective solutions, we can not only respond faster but also come out stronger. Let’s not waste this tragedy by defaulting to same ole same ole; now is the time to evolve and emerge better. Change our government inefficiencies, hire locals and build better. I love LA!
SUMMARY: Let's rebuild smarter and emerge better by changing government inefficiencies and hiring locals to build better
LABEL: Build Back Better
SUBCAT_DESC: Comments advocate for rebuilding with climate resilience in mind, focusing on modern infrastructure improvements like underground power lines, fire-resistant materials, and sustainable building practices while allowing temporary housing solutions during reconstruction.

CONTENT:
Preventing future disasters should be 1st priority. Get power lines underground, create highly accessible documentation around how to build a fire-resistant home, enforce new landscaping regulations to minimize spread potential.

Refining our ability to respond should they arise again should be 2nd. Provide LA residents with a 5-minute video explaining what to do in case of a future fire, perform an in-depth postmortem analyzing the emergency team response and determine any process changes that should be made.
SUMMARY: Preventing future disasters by implementing fire-resistant measures should be the priority over quickly rebuilding.
LABEL: Proactive Resilience First
SUBCAT_DESC: Comments advocate for rebuilding with climate resilience in mind, focusing on modern infrastructure improvements like underground power lines, fire-resistant materials, and sustainable building practices while allowing temporary housing solutions during reconstruction.

CONTENT:
I prefer to stay focused on where we go from here, rather than debate why stuff didn't happen in the past. We know what we need to do (e.g, utility under-grounding, firebreaks, fire prevention, fire hardening when (re)building, etc.). It will cost money (private, government). We know we have not had basic* transparency in past on government action (including our IOU monopolies), so let's design that differently from hereon too, perhaps leveraging 311 that we already use. All this can be piloted/tested in LA, but needs to be designed for statewide rollout, adapted for situations elsewhere. 

*basic in sense of: clear, accessible, responsive, and timely to average citizen - not in terms of endless dense reports commissioned by CPUC etc.
SUMMARY: Let's design for fire prevention, fire hardening, and transparency when rebuilding.
LABEL: Proactive Resilience Measures
SUBCAT_DESC: Comments advocate for rebuilding with climate resilience in mind, focusing on modern infrastructure improvements like underground power lines, fire-resistant materials, and sustainable building practices while allowing temporary housing solutions during reconstruction.

It is also absurd that it is 2025 and we are still flushing our toilets and irrigating our yards with drinking water, if we are rebuilding, we should do so with greywater systems that reuse water from our sinks, showers and laundry  for watering landscapes and flushing.

CONTENT:
I totally concur with this remark. Our home insurance has more than doubled each year for the last two years and there is no end in site to the increases.  This is not sustainable.  It is no surprise that so many homeowners who lost their homes either were woefully uninsured or had no insurance.  

Also, what is not calculated in the rebuild costs is how much construction costs will rise due to the limited number of legitimate and qualified construction companies available in a crisis like this. It is completely understandable why we so many people are leaving for other states.
SUMMARY: Insurance costs have doubled in two years, making it unsustainable, and many homeowners were underinsured or uninsured when they lost their homes
LABEL: Insufficient Insurance Coverage
SUBCAT_DESC: Financial assistance and streamlined support systems are urgently needed for underinsured and uninsured residents affected by wildfires, with particular focus on helping them navigate complex insurance claims, rebuild under new codes, and bridge coverage gaps while preventing displacement.

CONTENT: I would see this as an area where state and federal monies, along with $$$ from the utilities,  can be used to rebuild smartly.  Roads and sidewalks can be rethought to increase the probability of being able to leave in time.  Unsafe, above ground lines can be eliminated.

CONTENT: The general public has no idea how emergency communications work, much less how ECC's & EM's are staffed, much less how easily overwhelmed 9-1-1 centers (with understaffed centers) are with floods of calls during events like this; and I could go on.  Clearly, there were failures in both the LA City and LA County responses in notifying the public.  Many fell back onto the Watch Duty app, which is privately funded and operated.  It proved itself to be a MORE reliable method of getting notification than from our paid city/county employees. LA should enter into a public/private partnership with Watch Duty, making it the single app to rely on.  For connecting with residents for resources, have your websites pre-made, ready to go prior launching.
SUMMARY: LA should partner with private Watch Duty app for emergency notifications as it proved more reliable than city/county systems.
LABEL: Private Sector Superior
SUBCAT_DESC: Comments express strong opposition to private control of utilities, advocating for public ownership, underground power lines, and greater accountability from both private companies and government agencies in infrastructure management and disaster response.

CONTENT: The burn map cannot be used to determine eligibility. There are thousands of residents displaced due to smoke/soot/ash damage that are within the 250 yard health advisory boundary of the burn and they aren’t eligible for assistance because they aren’t in the burn area even though they are just as displaced and have lost all their interior contents. We’re being hung out to dry.
SUMMARY: Residents outside burn area but within health advisory boundary are ineligible for assistance despite similar displacement and losses
LABEL: Inconsistent Eligibility Criteria
SUBCAT_DESC: Financial assistance and streamlined support systems are urgently needed for underinsured and uninsured residents affected by wildfires, with particular focus on helping them navigate complex insurance claims, rebuild under new codes, and bridge coverage gaps while preventing displacement.

CONTENT: The major lifelines of water, electricity, natural gas, and broadband/internet are absolutely required.  The pedestrian infrastructure was likely not impacted by the fires, but the rest obviously have been.  In addition to burying electrical, there should be separate standpipes between homes, in addition to standard hydrants, for fire department (or even homeowner) access, to support mitigation of any future events.  Better reservoir water management and better water infrastructure would help, but in the event of this particular incident, as we would say in the fire service 'is like trying to stop a train with a water hose'.  Just not possible. Which is why, better rebuilding with fire resistant materials is required.
SUMMARY: Build back with fire resistant materials and better infrastructure to support future mitigation efforts.
LABEL: Rebuild More Resilient
SUBCAT_DESC: Comments advocate for rebuilding with climate resilience in mind, focusing on modern infrastructure improvements like underground power lines, fire-resistant materials, and sustainable building practices while allowing temporary housing solutions during reconstruction.

Only thing I can add here is that given that good fraction of the community has to start from scratch, now is a good time to revisit infra related issues such as underground power and better broadband.

CONTENT:
Things to be addressed first in recovery:
1- Priority #1: Make sure all toxic debris has been cleared out (including charred structures, cars, and flora/trees). There should also be thorough environment analysis of the topsoil in: PP, Malibu, and Altadena- to make sure there are no toxins hiding in the ground that could lead to increased cancer rates in the future.
2-Secondary priority: Make sure that current occupants/tenants/homeowners DO NOT LOSE THEIR HOMES. Mandatory moratorium on mortgage payments and rent for the rest of 2025. People should not be made to pay for property that is burned out. 
3-Teritary priority: Generous assistance for home insurance policyholders as they attempt to rebuild (maybe ~$50k per household?)
SUMMARY: Mandatory moratorium on mortgage payments and rent for 2025 to prevent homeowners/tenants from losing homes due to burned property
LABEL: Prioritize Homeowners Tenants
SUBCAT_DESC: Financial assistance and streamlined support systems are urgently needed for underinsured and uninsured residents affected by wildfires, with particular focus on helping them navigate complex insurance claims, rebuild under new codes, and bridge coverage gaps while preventing displacement.

CONTENT:
Modular, low-cost, ecologically-sound housing, manufactured en masse in our backyard. See SoLA Model Z in South Los Angeles as one excellent example. They are walking the walk and ready to plug in (I toured their factory last week)  

Also would love to see novel ideas for neighborhoods to rebuild together, not only to gain economy of scale and efficiency with materials, etc. but to plan housing layouts in a new way. Perhaps one block with 10 homes each sacrifices 10% of footprint to allow for one communal lot to be used with more of a "village" mentality i.e small farming, open space for kids, etc. This may seem utopic, but I think many people are close to being in this mindset already. If we can rebuild, let's try it differently!
SUMMARY: Let's rebuild differently with novel neighborhood ideas and modular housing to create a "village" mentality

CONTENT:
When it comes to managing dollars, people want to see the overall dollars being distributed via programs. 

If there's 10,000 homes and businesses burnt, and we have $6B collectively raised for every single program from mental health to temporary housing, to environmental cleanups...

That's nearly $600,000 per structure on top of their insurance payments. If that's the case, just give them the bulk of the money and let the communities self organize and solve their repair. Pool a portion of the money into local government accounts for things like rebuilding schools and repairing sidewalks. 

If the number is much much less, like $1B, mostly not cash, and not all available today, then fine build it all out slowly with programs.
SUMMARY: Give individuals bulk of money to self-organize and solve repairs, pooling some for community needs like schools and sidewalks
LABEL: Direct Cash Assistance
SUBCAT_DESC: Financial assistance and streamlined support systems are urgently needed for underinsured and uninsured residents affected by wildfires, with particular focus on helping them navigate complex insurance claims, rebuild under new codes, and bridge coverage gaps while preventing displacement.

CONTENT: We can't rebuild alone. We need help from EVERYONE -- the state and county government, from public donors, from community groups, and most of all each other. There are resources available but information about and access to services is all over the place. We desperately need a functioning hub with vetted information that will put us in contact with each other and provide information on how to access additional funding and support. And that hub MUST be virtual -- many of us had to move far away to find affordable housing and can't attend in person events.
SUMMARY: We need a virtual hub with vetted info to access funding/support, as resources are scattered and many were displaced.

CONTENT: Part of the beauty of Altadena was it's connection to nature. We should aim to protect and restore that while striving to build a more fire-safe community. Or, waivers need to be given so that the County of LA can allow its communities to rebuild many of the historic homes that were lost, without adding to the burden of the rebuild.  

This can be addressed in many ways, via grants, tax rebates and tax amnesty programs.

CONTENT: I was in a fire recovery support group, and hearing the stories of people waiting in lines for vouchers for 8 hours is a joke. Working class people don't have the time for that. Older people shouldn't have to stand in a line for that long. And the people waiting in that line weren't even all guaranteed relief! The whole day passed and people after the 400th person were denied. Also - of the people who received relief vouchers, they then had to go to a Walmart to cash them (which some employees didn't even know how to do). There is one too many steps involved. A relief voucher should be minimal steps. What if people don't have easy access to transportation? And why is the government relying on private corporations? It's just so dystopic.
SUMMARY: Waiting in 8-hour lines for vouchers isn't relief for working class and older people, and process was flawed with too many steps
LABEL: Insufficient Government Support

CONTENT: The state & many cities are planning for more growth & density, w/o paying attention to flood plains & fire prone areas. Even if the area is a "high opportunity area" if it's a flood plain per FEMA, it's highly irresponsible to put more people in the path of danger. We're now having more 100-year and 500-year storms and we must adapt to climate change, not ignore it. Same goes for tsunami zones, sea level rise & erosion, we should stop advocating for false solutions like sea walls & advocate for managed retreat instead. The city must have real community engagement and conduct drills so residents can be prepared for natural disasters. Language access is crucial, not only simple to understand, but translate messages to languages people speak.
SUMMARY: State plans for growth & density ignore flood plains & fire prone areas, putting more people in danger; we must adapt to climate change.

CONTENT: We're already in a rent crisis, and the wildfires are just fanning the flames. Everyone is being exploited; not just residents, but also small business owners! CONTENT:
The government's attacking insurance, as someone from the southeast US, is strange. Governmental agencies let the city of LA develop and sprawl into high fire-risk areas. Insurance companies, like when people build beachfront homes in hurricane country, jacked up the insurance rates. When an insurance company says an area is dangerous, believe them.

Forcing other taxpayers to supplement a "wood home in a tinderbox" is ludicrous. Saying it's the homeowners' fault for having a home in a tinderbox is likewise insane; they aren't fire experts.

The blame for the Palisades fire's destruction lays at the feet of the negligent county, city, and state level officials who allowed people to build/buy homes and root their lives in the line of fire.

CONTENT:
Considering all of the electrical batteries in EV's or hybrids that melted into the drainage system (and future ones) along with all of the hazardous materials that when burned cause new toxins to form, in addition to their regular hazardous status when not burned, this needs to be a priority.  It was not well communicated to the NIMBY's that trucks/debris etc., would be traversing their roads and/or that certain locations would be used for packaging of those materials.  Better pre-planning of sites and better communications to the communities at large would reduce these kinds of concerns.

Greater open space between residential areas and wild-land interfaces should be required to support defensible space between the areas.
SUMMARY: "Greater open space between residential areas and wild-land interfaces should be required."
LABEL: "Build Back Better"
SUBCAT_DESC: Residents strongly advocate for thorough soil and environmental testing before rebuilding, emphasizing the critical need to identify and remediate toxic contamination from the fires to protect long-term community health and property values.

CONTENT: Address foreign ownership of homes that the owners do not live in or if it is not their primary home. Housing is a complex problem which is more acute now that we just lost many thousands of homes to fire and wont see them rebuilt for years but that seems like low hanging fruit.
SUMMARY: Address foreign ownership of homes not used as primary residences
LABEL: Allow More Residents
SUBCAT_DESC: Housing affordability crisis requires immediate action through increased density, zoning reform, and multi-family development to combat rising rents and displacement, particularly in the wake of wildfire destruction.

CONTENT: Fed and State need to give municipalities mandates AND resources to address natural disasters. There need to be timelines and requirements. There needs to be more public awareness. There were a lot of warning signs - the insurance companies cancelling policies was the canary in the coal mine and government should have acted more swiftly. Too many devastating fires have happened in a short span of timeframe to not know there is a problem. Local government needs to be transparent about the shortcomings. A lot of good bills are being introduced this year but there's still a lot of gaps like HOAs. We are in a dire situation which is likely to get worse after these stopgap measures end like moratoriums on insurance carriers dropping insured.
SUMMARY: Fed and State should give municipalities mandates and resources to address natural disasters, ensuring transparency and swift action
LABEL: Public Over Private
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: We need transparency and accountability from insurance companies, as well as from oil and gas companies. Insurance claims need to be met. Politicians must stand up to extractive capitalism. Yet we also do need to recognise that disasters are going to increase in number and scale. Life is uncertain and responsibility and accountability start with individuals. There is no magic bullet, just a hundred and one acts of daily accountability and learning to do more with less. Asking for specific ideas is great and thank you for doing so, yet what we are faced with is changing mindsets and learning to address our issues systemically. Corporations AND their shareholders need to stop driving the 'growth and increasing profits are forever' mentality.
SUMMARY: Insurance companies and corporations must be held accountable and stop driving the 'growth and profits forever' mentality.
LABEL: Private Sector Blame
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: Comprehensive testing of the soil in and near the burn zones is essential. The state needs to coordinate and pay for this. This impacts those of us who have houses standing as well as those who want to rebuild. We want to ensure that we aren't living in a hazmat site, and without testing, we won't know for sure. Failure to test and remediate properly now will have terrible health impacts later, and will also have negative impacts on our property values.
SUMMARY: Soil testing is essential to ensure we're not living in a hazmat site and to prevent future health impacts and property value loss.
LABEL: Prioritize Safety Measures
SUBCAT_DESC: Residents strongly advocate for thorough soil and environmental testing before rebuilding, emphasizing the critical need to identify and remediate toxic contamination from the fires to protect long-term community health and property values.

CONTENT: Soil of all properties must be remediated and tested afterward.  This includes both soil of properties with standing structures and the entirety of properties with destroyed structures, not just within the ash footprint.  Also, people should be strongly encouraged to remove toxic substances, such as lead and asbestos, from their homes and properties rather than encapsulating them.  If they are merely encapsulated, these substances will become part of the toxic aftermath of the next fire...and there will be more fires.
SUMMARY: Soil must be remediated and toxic substances removed from properties to prevent future toxic aftermath.
LABEL: Build Back Better

CONTENT: In addition to the clear failures in both fires, both locations, for notifications, I personally watched an area of Hollywood evacuated by emergency alert, then watched as approximately 10,000 cars all attempted to exit out of the area at exactly the same time; leading to some being stuck in their garages up to 2 hours after the initial evacuation notice went out, because of the massive log-jam of traffic. This was a complete failure in terms of communication/notification.  There was NO traffic control in advance of this notification which should have been required before sending it, especially for a high-density area.  There's no identified evacuation routes for these types of situations.
SUMMARY: Evacuations were hindered by 10,000 cars exiting at once, causing log-jams and trapping people in garages
LABEL: Overwhelming Evacuation Routes
SUBCAT_DESC: Comments express strong concerns about inadequate evacuation infrastructure and safety risks of increasing density in fire-prone areas, particularly criticizing current development patterns and emergency response systems.

CONTENT: Insurance companies make their money on being able to predict risk. I think if an insurer says it's too risky to live somewhere, we should listen.

CONTENT: Insurance is a key lever that needs to be addressed here, in service to the whole of the economy.  Insurance providers have known for DECADES about the risks they face with respect to climate, and as an industry, they have not acted with enough innovative approaches to changing incentives for more regenerative decisions.  They have not faced the truth of what is facing all of us with respect to climate risk, and they are brittle and wholly unprepared from a business model perspective to respond to the realities of what they are facing.  We need to redesign business models, incentives, and policies to face the realities of the calamities that we are facing as a community.  There is only going to be more of the same in the future.
SUMMARY: Insurance providers have not acted with enough innovative approaches to changing incentives for more regenerative decisions
LABEL: Private Sector Failure
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT:
Insurance companies should be held responsible for paying the claims on the policies that they willingly sold to residents in the affected areas.  But we also have to acknowledge that they are beholden to their shareholders and will non-renew or exit CA if they can't make a profit.

It could help to require insurance companies to offer incentives for more fire-resistant construction.  Loosening regulations on the insurance industry is something I'm hesitant to support, but if insurance rates are determined by market forces and not a government commission, it could lead to more companies entering the market which would keep prices in check.  Rates will still be higher, but CA rates are lower than many other states with lower disaster risk.
SUMMARY: Insurance companies should be held responsible for paying claims on policies sold, but may exit CA if they can't make a profit.
LABEL: Private Sector Limitations
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: Money should be going straight to the people affected by the fires and those in the city that are already housing insecure. Not to small businesses or non-profit middlemen that sap funding for their own gain. Funds should be used to build new affordable housing and fund direct relief to low-income/migrant families. Without affordable and safe housing and stable finances people do not have a chance to obtain employment or start their own businesses.
SUMMARY: "Funds should go directly to people affected by fires and housing insecure individuals, not middlemen, for affordable housing and direct relief."
LABEL: Prioritize Direct Aid
SUBCAT_DESC: Financial assistance and streamlined support systems are urgently needed for underinsured and uninsured residents affected by wildfires, with particular focus on helping them navigate complex insurance claims, rebuild under new codes, and bridge coverage gaps while preventing displacement.

CONTENT:
Regarding insurance claims and premiums, no one should have any issues at all with insurance claims. Insurance companies should be lowering cost and premiums vs. raising them. When it's a known fact that insurance companies have more money than banks and are collecting around the clock; I find it hard to believe that they are somehow living paycheck to paycheck. Besides, this is the business they chose. If insurance companies want to raise cost, they should be required to provide something more like free legal assistance for tenants and undocumented immigrants. 

New requirements before permitting building of homes and buildings, fire prevention methods and materials required before issuing any permits. City, County, and State level.
SUMMARY: Insurance companies should lower costs and premiums, not raise them, and provide free legal assistance to vulnerable populations.
LABEL: Private Sector Accountability
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: The plain fact is that NO ONE can afford this. My family is in a relatively privileged position where we had insurance and did not lose our jobs, but we don't know if we will be able to afford to rebuild. If we can't afford it, who can? What will our town be if it's just turned over to deep pocketed developers? We need help, and direct financial assistance to residents is the only way to preserve this town.

CONTENT: I cannot tell you what a nightmare it has been for those of us who have homes still standing to navigate insurance. Most of the information at town halls and webinars was for total loss, which is a more clearly defined insurance process. The rest of us were basically expected to go back into our toxic homes and had to fight like hell for every ounce of ALE and smoke remediation to be covered. We are so grateful for Ricardo Lara and his staff for their help putting pressure on the insurance companies, but it would be great if the agents had the capacity to offer more guidance and support
SUMMARY: Insurance companies didn't provide enough guidance, had to fight for coverage; grateful for Ricardo Lara's help

When a person calls their insurance company after a fire - you'd expect they'd receive an A-Z step by step "Here's how to file and complete your claim." Instead, they get "You're in a dark room, find the light switch"

The insurance piece of this is very complicated. But the claims part need not be. This is something where the Dept can make quick and substantive changes overnight. Force guidelines for claims to be clear and easy to follow.

CONTENT: The insurance market is a disaster. I was told days before the fire that my insurance carrier no longer met the rating requirements of my mortgage lender so I cancelled my insurance policy effective 1/10/25 while my wife and I were getting quotes with other companies. We were going to be underwritten on 1/10/25 but the moratorium after the fires stopped that process and we couldn’t reinstate our previous policy because I cancelled it before the fires but it wouldn’t fulfill my mortgage requirements anyways. After 10 days of no insurance immediately after the fires, we joined the FAIR plan and then got charged an insane amount from our lender for the lapse in insurance coverage. My house didn’t burn and still no word from other insurers!
SUMMARY: Insurance companies dropped me right before the fire, then I was charged for a lapse in coverage
LABEL: Private Sector Failure
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

SUMMARY: California govt is to blame for lack of insurance after 14,000 homes lost; need to fix insurance problem
LABEL: Government is Responsible
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: California's insurance system requires a complete overhaul—it is currently more complicated than the tax code. This issue must be addressed in clear, straightforward terms before any funds are allocated. Otherwise, the same problems will arise during the next disaster.
SUMMARY: Insurance system needs overhaul to simplify and clarify before allocating funds
LABEL: Private Sector Inefficiency
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: California needs to call in Federal assistance to manage the entire state. Too much of the forest is left unkept. Need to increase logging of old forest so that areas can be managed with planting of new growth. Open it up the private companies to manage.
SUMMARY: "Open it up to private companies to manage"
LABEL: Private Management Preferred
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: Everyone is financially stressed by this. Being self-employed is tough but especially when the documentation for assistance is based on paperwork that you wouldn't normally have. Adjust the requirements. I can't prove paychecks, or - as requested - prove lack of paychecks (impossible to prove a negative) to get assistance. Or provide a named location for work when I worked from home (and computer doesn't recognize that as a location) SoCal is known for its entrepreneurialism but then focuses on paperwork of employee status.
SUMMARY: Self-employed individuals struggle to prove loss due to rigid documentation requirements; adjust requirements to accommodate non-traditional work arrangements
LABEL: More Flexible Eligibility
SUBCAT_DESC: Small and local businesses impacted by LA wildfires need immediate financial assistance through accessible grants, tax relief, and low-interest loans to prevent closures and maintain community character while avoiding exploitation by large corporations or speculators.

CONTENT: I'm so sorry you have to deal with that. Truly, my heart is breaking for you. Though I would ask you investigate the actual reason you have lost your coverage. Start by reading about the fact that California does not allow insurers to raise premiums by more than x%. This sounds nice in theory, but in reality what happens is insurance companies are left with no choice but to cancel coverage, as it is not economically realistic for them to continue providing coverage in increasingly high fire-risk areas without raising premiums.
SUMMARY: Insurance companies cancel coverage due to California's premium raise cap, forcing them to abandon high fire-risk areas
LABEL: Private Sector Constrained
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: The entire insurance system in California should be completely reimagined. There must be a system that is accessible, cannot be canceled or reduced based on statewide costs and mandates and is sustainable over time.
SUMMARY: Insurance system should be reimagined to be accessible and sustainable.
LABEL: Public Over Private
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: One massive issue we had here in Northern CA is that insurance coverage for temporary housing only kicks in when the evacuation order is mandatory. This means that people with fewer financial resources (including seniors) are forced to wait until the very last minute to leave--putting themselves in great danger and making the situation more difficult and dangerous for first responders, as well. And because lodging coverage stops as soon as evac orders are lifted, people here were forced to return to unsafe situations, with no running water, no power and no internet (at a time when kids were still doing remote learning due to COVID). The state needs to be aware of this issue and work with insurance providers to resolve it.
SUMMARY: State should work with insurance providers to resolve issue of coverage timing and duration
LABEL: Public Over Private
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: California should compete with all forms of insurance in the state with a public option.  What we currently have are companies who effectively subsidize TV and other media with endless advertising yet will do everything in their power to delay and then deny your claims.  If the Federal Govt. is going to be less likely to pay-out (for one reason or another) in what would've previously been considered a disaster, we may have no other choice.
SUMMARY: California should have a public insurance option to counter private companies that prioritize profits over claims.
LABEL: Public Over Private
SUBCAT_DESC: California's insurance system is failing homeowners affected by wildfires, with companies leaving the market, claims being denied, and policies becoming unaffordable or unavailable, requiring a complete overhaul of the state's insurance regulations and marketplace structure.

CONTENT: The economy already favors the wealthy and successful, so these emergencies require special protections and provisions for underserved small businesses that need extra help to recover.
SUMMARY: Underserved small businesses need extra help to recover from emergencies.
LABEL: Prioritize Underserved Businesses
SUBCAT_DESC: Small and local businesses impacted by LA wildfires need immediate financial assistance through accessible grants, tax relief, and low-interest loans to prevent closures and maintain community character while avoiding exploitation by large corporations or speculators.

CONTENT:
The small business support that exists right now is a complete joke. They are high interest loans that are few and far between, businesses in palisades are battling with their internet provider for early cancellation - it’s not early cancellation. There is nothing to go back to!! Some of them are on the hook for over $10,000! These are everyday people
Who showed up day in and day out for our community and the county/city/state is turning their backs on them. 

Why are their no streamlined grants? Incentive them to say.
SUMMARY: "High interest loans are not support, businesses are being left with huge debts, no streamlined grants or incentives are being offered."
LABEL: Inadequate Relief Mechanisms
SUBCAT_DESC: Small and local businesses impacted by LA wildfires need immediate financial assistance through accessible grants, tax relief, and low-interest loans to prevent closures and maintain community character while avoiding exploitation by large corporations or speculators.

CONTENT: I kindly urge you to consider hiring and training individuals from Los Angeles for this work. We can make a positive impact by reducing bureaucratic barriers and giving our local community a chance. The job market in LA is genuinely challenging right now, and supporting our own can bring hope and opportunity to those in need. Hire our own, train our own, and stop with the six-month hiring process. People are losing everything, and we aren't requiring these contractors to hire those affected.
SUMMARY: "Hire locals affected by the fire to rebuild, reducing bureaucratic barriers and supporting the community in need."
LABEL: Prioritize Local Hires
SUBCAT_DESC: Small and local businesses impacted by LA wildfires need immediate financial assistance through accessible grants, tax relief, and low-interest loans to prevent closures and maintain community character while avoiding exploitation by large corporations or speculators.

CONTENT: The entertainment industry, along with a lot of Los Angeles, has lost jobs over the past five years. We should focus on returning these individuals to work in our community whenever possible. While I get we have an outside contractor with expertise in this area, why don't we require them to hire people who have lived in LA for an extended period? Let's support those who have lost their jobs and those who currently reside here. We have a community in the know in the future, then.
SUMMARY:
Here's the extracted and re-written comment in 25 words or less, along with a 3-word subcategory label: 
"Prioritize local hiring for disaster recovery efforts to support those who have lost jobs

CONTENT:
People need money to put food on their table and a roof over their head. But any business recovery needs to be cognizant of the needs of the community. It would be a shame if pure market interests are what dictated the kind of business and industries that get created and not the interests of the people who live there.
We don't need anymore extractive business's like mining, real estate speculation, and warehousing but more restorative/regenerative business like food coops, watershed protection , and habitat restoration.
SUMMARY: Business recovery should prioritize community needs over market interests
LABEL: Community Led Recovery
